items.title: ‘Conserve Energy’: New York City Begs Residents to Help Avoid Outages
items.abstract: An emergency alert was sent to cellphones across the city as New Yorkers endured their fourth day of sweltering heat. It appears to have worked: Power usage dropped in the hours that followed.

items.title: The City That Never Sleeps Is Waking Up Later
items.abstract: Some 400 special electric meters in New York apartments provide a shifting view of power use while people are stuck inside.

items.title: Questions for: ‘How New York City Gets Its Electricity’
items.abstract: Where does the power for your electricity come from: wind, water, nuclear, natural gas, coal or solar?

items.title: City Makes Test Scores Available on the Web
items.abstract: Parents in New York will be able to log on to see how their children did on the new Common Core reading and math tests.

items.title: Water Pricing in Two Thirsty Cities: In One, Guzzlers Pay More, and Use Less
items.abstract: Both Fresno, Calif., and Santa Fe, N.M., face dire water shortages, but only one has embraced tiered pricing, where heavy users pay much more per gallon.
